title: 10 Enviable Oscars Looks From Years Past - The New York Times
text:
10 Enviable Oscars Looks From Years Past By THE NEW YORK TIMES FEB. 25, 2016 We all remember Barbra’s see-through pants, Bjork’s swan dress and Cher’s headdresses. But what about the more-wearable looks of the Academy Awards? Below, some of the most coveted (and imitated) outfits in the ceremony’s history. ( See this year’s here .) Photo Vivien Leigh with Laurence Olivier in 1940. Credit Associated Press Photo Vivien Leigh in Irene, 1940 
Created by a now-forgotten designer associated with a now-forgotten department store (Bullocks Wilshire), this poppy-dappled dress could nonetheless be easily imagined on the stars of today. Photo Mike Todd and Elizabeth Taylor in 1957. Credit AP Photo ​Elizabeth Taylor in Helen Rose, 1957 
Perhaps less memorable for the draped gown than the readily monetized accessories: wrap, handbag, gloves and a Cartier diamond tiara given to Taylor by her third husband, Mike Todd. Photo Audrey Hepburn, right, with George Cukor, the director, in 1968. Credit Rolls Press/Popperfoto/Getty Images ​Audrey Hepburn in Givenchy, 1968 
More typically remembered for her “Breakfast at Tiffany’s” little black dresses, Hepburn was ahead of her time in this sequin-and-flower-encrusted, Empire-waist, bow-bedecked dress with a cutout over the solar plexus. Photo Lauren Hutton in 1975. Credit Michael Montfort/Michael Ochs Archives, via Getty Images ​Lauren Hutton in Halston, 1975 
A simple banded and plunging Greek-goddess style that has ebbed and flowed over the decades. Photo Val Kilmer And Cher. Credit Ron Galella/WireImage ​Cher in Bob Mackie, 1984 
Before this collaboration went totally haywire, and when the nude look was still a glimmer in J-Lo’s eye, this sequined gold sheath caused a sensation. Photo Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins, right. Credit Vince Bucci/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images ​Susan Sarandon in Dolce & Gabbana, 1996 
Twenty years later , people still remember how perfectly this billowy, coppery satin ballgown coordinated with the Best Actress winner’s coif. Photo Cate Blanchett in 1999. Credit Michael Caulfield/Associated Press ​Cate Blanchett in John Galliano, 1999 
From the front, it looked like a simple slipdress. On the back: a pastoral scene of a hummingbird feeding on flowers that drove paparazzi wild. Photo Jennifer Lopez in 2003. Credit Frank Micelotta/Getty Images ​Jennifer Lopez in Valentino, 2003 
Nominated for nothing, Ms. Lopez, at the time the fiancée of Ben Affleck, nonetheless dominated style reports in a seafoam, one-shouldered confection inspired by a 1967 dress worn by Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. Photo Marion Cotillard in 2008. Credit Chris Pizzello/Associated Press ​Marion Cotillard in Jean Paul Gaultier, 2008 
This French actress made a splash in this white-scaled mermaid gown with train and simple, sideswept hair. Photo Lupita Nyong’o in 2014. Credit Noel West for The New York Times ​Lupita N’yongo in Prada, 2014 
The breakout star of “12 Years a Slave” with a trace of Ms. Hutton’s Halston, now in pale blue, with coordinated manicure and headband. More on NYTimes.com
